title: To be worth arguing about
review: A movie must first of all be interesting: it must have, if not a coherent point of view, at least a worked-out, thought-provoking set of themes, some kind of imaginative contact with the world as we know it. "Joker," an empty, foggy exercise in second-hand style and second-rate philosophizing, has none of that. Besotted with the notion of its own audacity - as if willful unpleasantness were a form of artistic courage - the film turns out to be afraid of its own shadow, or at least of the faintest shadow of any actual relevance.4 out of 8 found this helpful.Was this review helpful?Sign into vote.Permalink

title: A Cinematic Masterpiece. An Outstanding Performance By Joaquin.
review:
10/out of MF 10. Forget the media fear mongering. This was a relatable film because I am a female with some mental health issues and it covered that aspect with respect and the troubles that go along with being cut off of medication & services. Joaquin's performance is indeed Oscar worthy (not that it even matters to him) and it is on par with Ledger's. It also comes together nicely with a twist I didn't expect in the Batman universe. Anyone who has an issue with this cinematic masterpiece should stick to PG fluffy bunny Marvel films because this Alan Moore material is for us big kids. Go see this film.
Also on a side note I attended the movie with 3 other female friends who all LOVED it so this media outrage about it being only for a certain demographic is completely ridiculous. So yes some of us women are big fans of these films and I hope we continue to get quality cinema such as this.4 out of 8 found this helpful.Was this review helpful?Sign into vote.Permalink

title: Joaquin phoenix....WOW...
review:
Joker is undoubtedly the best movie of this year and one of the best in recent times.
When Joaquin phoenix was cast as joker I was a sceptical but after watching this film I can confidently say, he has full justice to this iconic character. His Maniac laugh, his mood swings, his dancing, makeup everything is perfect.
Now, joker is not a superhero movie it's more like a psychological thriller. It's dark and haunting and at times very disturbing. The background music is great and even though the story is slow paced, it has some surprises.
If you are a joker fan like me you will love it, if you love great cinema, you will love it.
Just keep one thing in mind, this is fiction, not a reality.
I have seen some of the criticizing the film based on some absurd reasons. They couldn't find anything wrong in the film but they thought it inspires gun violence and glorifies crime. Let's me tell you, It doesn't.4 out of 8 found this helpful.Was this review helpful?Sign into vote.Permalink

title: This may be one of the most important works of mainstream art in our time.
review: The only emotion I was able to understand after watching this film for the first time was disturbed. It invoked one of the longest and thought-provoking conversations I've had after watching a film. One of the biggest being its portrayal of mental illness, which may have been the most realistic I've seen, and the graphic violence. Only after watching it a second time did I realize how little violence there is in the film. The way Todd Phillips was able to make the viewer feel so strongly about the protagonist's journey throughout is a testament to him, Joaquin Phoenix and anyone involved in the film, especially the way the cinematographer used colors. It balanced an original story and comic book origin story flawlessly and after the second viewing, was able to look past it's 'not so' graphic nature and understand everything Arthur was going through and was somehow able to empathize and disagree with a character at the same time as they slipped into madness. This may be one of the most important works of mainstream art in our time.5 out of 11 found this helpful.Was this review helpful?Sign into vote.Permalink

title: The worst part of having a mental illness is people expect you to behave as if you don't
review:
First of all I'd like to say "HATS OFF TO TODD PHILIPS AND JOAQUIN PHOENIX". If you're a cinephile and haven't seen this movie on the bug screen, you're missing something!
The movie explores the life of Arthur Fleck and shows us how an ordinary man becomes the JOKER.
Daringly dark, this movie left me and many others speechless! No one was clapping when it ended, because the movie itself is a slap on the face of society! Everyone EVERYONE is a result of circumstances. This movie doesn't care about anything, it doesn't sugarcoat lies, it doesn't confuse reality with fiction, it takes the reality and puts a fictous yet amazingly real-like story in it! Do we take mental illness seriously? NO. Does this movie warns us of the consequences? YES. Should we relate to this movie and feel sympathy for Joker? NO. You know what ignorance and suppression leads to? It leads to JOKER!
Coming to the cinematic aspects of the movie, believe me when I say this, "Joaquins acting was TOP TIER"! Credit goes to Todd Philips too for creating an amazing yet dark environment and daring to implement this story! Cinematography was on point and in fact one of the best that I've seen! I'm saying this again because no matter how many tines I say this it won't be enough, Joaquin acted as if he WAS Joker! This performance tops that of "Her" and will always live in cinematic history as one of the best EVER!
It would be needless to say that you should see this because YOU SHOULD SEE THIS!
Talking about my experience in cinema, I was shocked and SHAKING when the movie ended! The last 15 mins of the movie were one of the finest and intense piece of cinema ever made!
Joker shakes the society, slaps it's face, and puts forward a question, "Where are we going as a society?"

title: This movie is beautiful, Joaquin Phoenix Would Make Heath Ledger Proud
review: This movie is beautiful. The message they deliver is immediately felt: it's portraying our society as a whole in the movie. This shows us exactly how some people are treated with disrespect, and being completely isolated as if they're not even a human being.Not only that, but Joaquin Phoenix's portrayal as Arthur Flex is astounding. You can see the high amount of time, and effort he's put on to being this character. He really hits home in the laughing, shows Arthur's struggles immensely with society in every scene. Phoenix also does an amazing job showing the descent into madness slowly, which just makes you feel even more terrible for the character Arthur Fleck, and what society had done to him. He really might've made Heath Ledger smiling down at him, saying: "you've restored my Joker legacy".Speaking of the descent into Joker, that was also handled very well. We first start off seeing Arthur as a weak, willed character. He slowly walks up the stairs in a weird, almost saddened way. He has a shaky voice, and almost zero confidence in himself. Arthur was pretty much broken down: a human that society treated as non-existent.However, when he becomes Joker, we immediately see he's happy as can be, dancing to his own music in his head down the steps as shown in the trailer and the movie. He actually feels more confident, not scared to express himself, albeit in a twisted way of course.I suggest you give this masterpiece a watch, you won't regret it.

title: Open up your empathy and you will be hurt deeply
review: One of the best, maybe even the best, movies I have seen in the last and in this year so far. A misunderstood movie if you read the reviews on the news. Is it brutal? Yes. Is it shocking? Yes. Does it cheer people up to become violent? No. This movie asks the audience to look behind the obvious. It asks us to reflect ourselves, as the person we are on our own and the society we builded up. As an empath I was deeply touched and hurt by the suffering of Arthur Fleck, the main character. His development is relatable and performed brilliantly by a Joaquin Phoenix in best form. JP is transforming in both characters, Arthur and then becoming more and more the Joker, so very commiting that it will take your breath. The score underlines perfectly the feelings of the main character and if you open up, this movie will get under your skin. It is an emotional ride with social criticism at it's realest.2 out of 3 found this helpful.Was this review helpful?Sign into vote.Permalink

title: Excellent example of mental health portrayal in film!
review: Aside from the storytelling of how the Joker came to be, this film beautifully captured the true essence of what it means to be living with a mental illness in a society that struggles to accept and understand it. The inaccuracies and exaggerations that come with the portrayal of mental illness in movies are all things we are prone to see and unfortunately fuel the stigma surrounding mental illness. It's refreshing to see a movie that tackles that stigma at its core by showing problems with society itself and how society treats individuals struggling with mental illness. It's very possible to merge entertainment with education and this movie exceeded that. While addressing issues like societal judgement and unhelpful medical staff, we were able to see it conveyed in a way that was also interesting and entertaining to see. The aspect that resonated with me the most was when Arthur called his therapist out for not listening and asking the same questions every week. Another aspect I found particularly interesting was how even though Arthur made efforts to get help and treatment, he wasn't given help when his therapist informed him that funding cuts were being made and he wouldn't be able to continue seeing her. Keeping the momentum of going to treatments and trying to get better is a long struggle that takes a lot of effort and work. Not being given the proper resources or support to keep that treatment can also be extremely detrimental and many are unfortunately put in this position. There are many individuals struggling with mental illness that do not have the resources to get help. I'm glad this point was reinforced in this film because there are individuals that want and seek help but simply do not have the resources to continue or find it. What made this movie unique was its ability to speak to a large audience, not only those struggling with mental illness but also those seeking to understand those that do. One of the ways Joaquin Phoenix prepared for his role was he studied up on how to portray Arthur's mental health struggles in the most accurate ways possible. One of the best ways we can tackle the stigma is to show more accurate portrayals and working alongside mental health professionals or psychologists so actors can portray those characters in the most accurate ways possible. While there are no justifications for Arthur's crimes, we did see how lack of empathy and support influenced the way he saw the world. The world can be a very cruel place, but the most important thing we can do is extend a helping hand to a stranger to spread a little joy in the world.

title: Disturbingly Realistic and Intense
review: Wow. Joker is easily the best movie I've seen in a long time. I started watching it on my TV yesterday and was so disturbed by it I turned it off, not sure whether I'd finish watching it. Of course I did, today.What made it so intense for me, besides what makes it so intense for everyone, is that I worked in state mental hospitals for many years and personally knew criminally insane people. Also, I lived in Manhattan during the 70's and the mood, background and vibe portrayed in the film was spot on. When I read afterward that it was supposed to be '81, I was surprised because it appeared and felt so much like the 70's. Besides the shabby condition of the city back then, the whole political thread replete with looting and rioting suggested the great blackout of '77 and its aftermath, not to mention that iconic 70's film, Taxi Driver.As for Joaquin Phoenix's performance well, there's nothing original to say here. His portrayal of a psychotic man was phenomenal. In fact, I had a boyfriend in the '70's who looked like Arthur and while he was crazy, he was the picture of sanity compared to Arthur/Joker.Joaquin had a great script to work with. As a would-be screenplay writer myself, I have a great deal of admiration for Todd Phillips and Scott Silver. In particular the pacing of the script was fantastic, especially the way the details of the past were revealed well into the film. I experienced a sense of ah, now I understand, learning that Arthur's compulsive laughing arose from brain damage sustained during a beating from mom's boyfriend, also that he had a very painful and abusive childhood which explained a lot. There was an amazing sense of development and growing intensity of the character and his madness. Yes, it was somewhat predictable that something big and violent would happen at the end, but who cared? Even the ending was perfect, in my opinion.There were two things that I questioned: one was that Arthur did not use drugs or alcohol. That was certainly different, for the times and for a person with his extreme problems. The other was that the actress who plays Sophie I thought might have been too pretty and "clean" looking, meaning also not into drinking or drugs; her skin and eyes too clear, her weight just right, neither too thin nor too fat. It was a little difficult to buy that she would have been involved with Arthur and I was relieved when her attitude toward him changed.Joker is an awesome film and I think it will be days before I can stop thinking about it. It deserves every possible award it can get.

title: Beautiful film, outstanding performance
review:
**BACKSTORY**
If I had to describe this movie in one word, it would simply be "beautiful". From the cinematography, to the acting & improvising, to the outstanding score, Joker is by far my favorite film ever made.If you knew me before this review, you'd know that I used to always choke up when asked what my favorite film was. I could not answer, and any answer I gave was not sincere in the slightest. This one however, is.**IS IT A COMIC FILM?**
I will say this; it's not really a comic book film at all, it is *loosely* based off of the character "Joker", so you shouldn't go into this film expecting it to be 1:1 lore, but in my opinion that plays a key in making it so good. If this movie (in my opinion,) went with a more comic-like approach, I would not have enjoyed it as much as I do and I am certain about this. Take my advice, when you watch this movie, don't go in with the mindset that you're gonna see "Joker" the comic villain, go in knowing this is a film about a guy who just wants to make people laugh & smile, and is challenged by the harshness of the world he lives in. With this mindset, I can guarantee you will enjoy this film much more, just keep the DC lore to a minimal.I know what you're thinking, "Well then, why is it called Joker?"
Like I said, it's *loosely* based off of the villain, and just a creative take on his backstory. Other than that, I don't really have any great explanations for you other than I simply enjoyed the film better by looking at it from a real world stand-point.**REVIEW**
Joaquin's portrayal of Arthur Fleck was phenomenal! He reportedly lost ~52 pounds for the part, and it really shows during the film. The performance is INCREDIBLE. His uncontrollable laugh comes to mind, as in every scene it happens you can just feel the suffering Arthur is going through, there's a particular scene that I won't go into details about, but let's just say finally catches a break, and it's all ruined from his nervous laughter. These moments really show just how great Joaquin is as portraying emotion, you can feel every bit of the character's emotions through this film. Everything from his uncontrollable laughter, to his adorable kid-like nature, everything about this character seems real and genuine like he lost himself in the part.Joker would not be what it is without the collaboration of Joaquin Phoenix and Todd Phillips. Had Phillips not given Phoenix so much freedom, I don't believe this film would have been as successful and Todd know's this, he's acknowledged it in an interview with (I forgot who) by saying something along the lines of "You wouldn't be a great director if you had an actor like Joaquin Phoenix on and NOT allow him such freedom." Not word-for-word, but you get the drift.When you watch this film, pay attention the colors. The colors beautifully match the feeling of every scene, with the orange and cyan blue light's it really makes for a beautiful film, you can pretty much find a great still in every single scene that is filmed.**OVERALL**
I give this movie a 10/10 and I've never felt so sure about a rating in my life. I think it is perfect, and honestly I do *not* want a sequel, this film is perfect as a one-off and I HIGHLY recommend you see it in theatre's before it is too late, this is not a film you want to miss the experience of seeing on the big screen.

title: A true masterpiece! And the oscar goes to .....
review:
I went to the theaters with a lot of expectations and I want disappointed .... I was actually blown away by this work of art .This movie was beautifully recorded, acted, and scripted from the opening scene to the ending credits .this movie gave us a new version of the joker that we've never seen before .. it gave the character the backstory he deserved .. and DC gave us the Joker solo movie we deserve... it's an origins story that will make you sympathize with joker,feel pity for him,laugh with him,like him, and of course fear him. This masterpiece was almost 2 hours long packed with a load of emotions .....I cant remember a single minute where i wasn't on the edge of my seat following every movement,every scene and every detail in this performance... and what a performance it was !!!!
Joaquin Phoenix nailed this role to no end, he was brilliant ! when the casting was revealed and we knew that Phoenix was getting the role I thought "yeah this guy could deliver " but I never expected this level of awesomeness and genius!
This film is a must see it will be remembered for a very long time ,I think it's by far the movie of the year and i guess both Phoenix and Todd Phillips deserve an academy award for this magnificent masterpiece !!

title: What he did was wrong, but was it the right thing to do at the moment ?
review:
The creative liberty given to the director/writers has given a new blend on the way you look at the joker. You don't need to be a fan of DC and/or the joker to engulf in to this epic saga of the journey of a transformation of a character. Every moment you have sympathy with the protagonist, he outsmarts you and surprises with the next move. The cringe it creates what happens next and results in another fiasco.All the time you ask yourself what he did was wrong, but was it the right thing to do at the moment ?
The so cleverly written movie was very well crafted and Joaquin Phoenix deserves all the respect on impersonating the soul of the character, Todd Phillip from his history of making movies has totally changed, He has become joined the big boys league now.
It would be a sin here not to mention clockwork orange and how someone is forcefully made into something, although joker here was more forced by the society.
And finally, Heath Ledger, the joker from the dark Knight, this was how a psychotic mind like him will become after few years past. Saying which one was better is a bad comparison to make. But with all respects to heath ledger, Joaquin Phoenix faced the gradient of character, which gives him the lead.

title: Heath ledger must be smiling from heaven
review:

title: Phoenix does it again..
review:
I was initially sold on on its very first trailer, where I instantly realised that Phoenix's portrayal of Joker's humble beginnings would be another exemplary performance to add to his already prestigious filmography.
Now after seeing the movie in full, my assumptions are confirmed.This was a perfect example of how villains are made. How a history of abuse, trauma and neglect has resulted in a mental illness that has left our protagonist to function as a lonely awkward outsider on the fringes of society.
Most people in such a state are but a shadow of themselves, yet for men like Arthur, having hit rock bottom and awakening to the conclusion of having nothing left to lose, they set themselves free, allowing their alter ego to come out and play. And there's nothing quite as dangerous as a sharp and calculating man who has a few screws loose; loose enough to twist that moral code that most of us keep firmly intact.Although pure perfection, for me, would have it ending 5mins earlier, as he stood on the bonnet of that cop car, amidst the rioting, practically praised as the prince of anarchy. Had the credits rolled right then, in my mind, figuratively speaking, I would have stood up and given an applause consisting of five full-blown claps (that's three claps more than I'm accustomed to giving).I'm happy that this was the movie that the wife and I chose as our date-night outing. Last time we went to the cinema together was 7 months ago and were pretty disappointed with what we watched. But not this time. This time, we praised it all the way back home.

title: A masterpiece indeed!
review:
I must say that I was very sceptic at first that I was actually going to like this movie, the reason being I was not very much of a Phoenix fun. BUT I was absolutely flabbergasted! His acting, his posture, his movements, his facial expressions - he nailed it, and he really deserves this rating 10. Beautiful shots as well largely contribute to a general feeling, "Oh, boy, the best two hours of my life."
The message: look around, 'jokers' are everywhere around us....unfortunately, it's we who make them us) who they are, it's their(our) own families who create jokers, it's the whole society, and the way they treat them from the moment they are born,who makes these Jokers, waiting their moment to explode. He is an antihero, misfortune permeates his whole life, but you simply cannot but sympathize with him...as you sow, so you shall reap.2 out of 3 found this helpful.Was this review helpful?Sign into vote.Permalink

title: Bucket list viewing.
review:
I'd been resisting seeing this film for weeks watching others and admittedly not really enjoying any of them. Finally there was nothing else of interest to watch so off we went.
The opening scene of laughter triggered a painfully visceral sense of discomfort. Like being hit with a 2X4 I was awake and focused. Like many others I did not expect this and I did not expect this from Todd Phillips so my bad on both counts. Powerful, moving and brilliant in many respects this seemed like a curtain going up to reveal a whole new form of film making. I couldn't help think of Dostoevsky's "The Idiot" and how it could be re-imagined so that today's audiences would flock to it. Using veils such as "the Joker" might just be the vehicle to make it work.
I'm also bemused at peoples comparisons to Heath Ledgers Joker. While the connection seems obvious, I'd suggest Ledger and Phoenix's joker should be judged independently as standalone works of creative brilliance.
Strangely I'm suddenly not interested in watching other comic book stories after seeing the Joker be they DC or Marvel.
If you like myself had/have any preconceived ideas, set them aside and see The Joker.

review:
Joker" is a 2019 film directed by Todd Phillips.
It is nothing but a message in favor of suffering people, forgotten and marginalized by the rest of society.
Today many people are just a mass of suppressants, selfish, cruel and exploiters towards the weakest needy. The reason why an individual behaves in a certain way does not matter. Only what others have seen count, I learned from third parties without making sure or investigating why he did it.
I hope the world changes.
May everyone realize that we are human beings who tend to do good but unfortunately we should move away from suppressors or those who represent antisocials. I hope everyone can realize how much we can do our best for ourselves and for the welfare of others. title: Let's dive deep!
review:
I heard a lot of people complaining about the fact that this Joker got nothing to do with Batman's Joker that we all know and love. Well, you're missing many points here!1-This movie is supposed to be a non-canon one, meaning it's more of else world story than it's a continuity.
2-The movie is made to tell the story of how society can drive a man into madness and they nailed it.
3-Up till this very moment, The Joker never had an origin story. In the comics you gonna have the vet accident, the failing comedian, the three jokers, the lazuras pit joker, etc. So why all the madness about a story that suggest a different background and taking a page from the comics as well while they do it resulting in the most believable and humane story ever!
4-The acting was great, the movie was meh! Seriously guys you're missing it all over again, if you think the acting is solid then the movie is solid cause this is a one man show, it tells the story from Arthur's perspective.Pay a good second watch to the movie and enjoy a masterpiece that we'll have to wait a while till we learn how to praise it.

title: Worthy of all the praise it can get
review: What is there to say about this movie that hasn't already been said? Joker is a meticulous, expertly crafted piece of art, in terms of writing, direction, cinematography, and especially performance. Every element of this film is a solid piece of the framework and each lends their strengths to each other in a way that hasn't been seen in a comic book movie before.From Pheonix's heart-wrenching, mesmerizing, and terrifying performance, to the tension building, tragic score, to the harsh depth of field that leaves the viewer in a dream-land, as if everything in the world is an illusion. There isn't a single element of Joker that isn't filled with passion and careful consideration. A week after seeing it and I've done nothing but think about each element more and more - it's a story that begs for repeat viewings, filled to the brim with detail, leaving space for theorizing and conspiring, the perfect way to do a Joker origin movie:"If I'm going to have a past, I'd rather it be multiple choice"The only slight downfalls of this near masterpiece is that in some parts it can feel a little repetitive, and it does heavily borrow from Scorcese films such as Taxi Driver & King of Comedy, but ultimately these are minor nitpicks in an unforgettable, unsettling, and thought-provoking narrative that will continue to be discussed and theorised for years.Filled with quotables, memorable moments, shocking moments, shocking moments with hints of Joker comedy, this is definitely the perfect Joker origin story, as well as an important message/warning to society regarding the 1%.

title: Cinematic Genius
review:
It's been 12 hours since I saw Joker at my local cinema and my head is still spinning.
I didn't get much sleep and I'm still trying to process what happened.
It was nothing short of a feast for the senses and I just wanted more.Make no mistake - this is cinematic brilliance at its highest level.
A masterpiece.
Hauntingly beautiful, magnificent, mesmerizing.
Stunning.
Chilling.
I honestly don't think I blinked during the two hours in fear of missing something.The onscreen world immediately captures you and pulls you in to an 80's Gotham City.
The thunderous Dolby Atmos soundtrack is beautiful, chilling and at times downright terrifying.If you are expecting a non-stop gore fest then you will be bitterly disappointed.
There are a handful of shootings.
What you will experience is a classic film of unprecedented genius, both artistically and technically.I must admit I went into the theatre with a bias towards Joaquin Phoenix.
Everyone has read the stories of his whacky antics and frequent meltdowns.
I'd seen his on set rant on talk show Jimmy Kimmel a few weeks back and thought him to be just another pretentious actor.
All is forgiven.
His performance in this film is truly breathtaking.Joker is not just another DC superhero film, it's a journey into the mind of a twisted psychopath who needed help but didn't get it.
For some reason, actors who have previously played this character (Nicholson, Ledger, Leto, Romero, etc.) have all turned in both sterling and mesmerizing performances.
But it's Phoenix who now wears the crown as The Clown Prince Of Crime.Here is my rather modest prediction come Oscar season.Best picture.
Best screenplay.
Best director.
Best cinematography.
Best actor in a leading role.
Best musical score.
Best sound editing.What I'm trying to say is this is undoubtably the best piece of modern cinema I have ever seen.P.S. For those uneasy about Gary Glitter coining in the royalties for his track in the film, his catalogue was bought out years ago by a UK based publishing company so he will not be receiving a dime for the tracks inclusion.

title: Joker is a victim of an uncaring society
review:
This movie is a story of mentally ill person being pushed out of society, abused by people around him and broken by people he idolize.
This isn't a some fictional story filled with CGI, and to some this isn't even a fictional story. There are lots of people who are treated just like Joker. They suffer in silence, their existence is treated as nuisance, their calls for help are called "toxic" or "privileged". Society so happily mistreat people, but then act in shock and horror when those people break.
Joker is a movie about pain and irony of the world. It shows how society treat those who are different and how it repays those who have dreams. This movie forces abusers to see the life of their victims, it shows the consequences of careless evil. That is why abusers and generally evil people can't stand this movie - because it shows them who the true villain is. Joker isn't the villain of this movie. He does lots of horrid things, the character should rot in jail for his actions, but shouldn't the people who made him suffer the same fate? Joker is a product of torture, so he lashes out against his torturers. Nothing more.By the way, it also have great comedic moments, but as Joker says himself: "Humor is subjective".

title: The dark cruel world of the Joker.
review: JOKER is a dark, depressing, moody, violent masterpiece. The film rest upon the shoulders of Joaquin Phoenix and he pulls it off brilliantly! The entire cast is awesome especially De Niro and Zazie Beetz.It's hard to believe the guy who directed The Hangover trilogy and Road Trip is the same guy who directed this punch in the gut brilliant flawless slow burn gritty glorious film.There is no Batman to battle or evil supervillain to play off of. This is the story of one man's journey into darkness and that is why Joaquin Phoenix's Joker is easily the best Joker that has ever graced the big screen in my opinion.Will Phoenix win the oscar? Probably not. I can't see that spineless (Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences) politically correct tool of an organization giving out any major awards to a film this good.Joker is the best movie I've watched in the past 10 years. The flick gets 10 out of 10 severed thumbs.If you didn't already know the story centers around Arthur Fleck a mentally troubled comedian as he embarks on a downward spiral of social revolution and bloody crime. It is his story, it is the world as he sees it.

title: A very uplifting movie !
review: This movie was a bit different from what I had expected yo see, in that, for a movie about a joker there are very few jokes, and very little humor. It is still very worth seeing, though. It does address the very real and pressing issue of income inequality, and the feelings of isolation and futility that many people feel today. These are really the most moving scenes of the movie, and the ones that really cast Arthur in the role of the every man we can all relate to. The way that he becomes an icon to all of his "clown" admirers, especially toward the end of the movie, was the most uplifting part of the movie. The fact that there is a scene that is very similair to the one shown in the original 1989 Batman film makes this film both a Batman and Joker origin story. The back ground music, cinematography, screenplay, and nost of all the acting by Mr Phoenix, and Mr. DeNiro a must see for all adult fans of the batman super hero genre.2 out of 3 found this helpful.Was this review helpful?Sign into vote.Permalink

title: Put on a happy face!
review: You won't actually be putting on a happy face while watching Joker, what you'll be doing instead is witness the greatest film of the year and the Oscar-worthy performance of Joaquin Phoenix. His performance is extraordinary, every single time you hear him laugh, you know something is wrong and you start to feel uncomfortable, add all that to his facial expressions and acting skills and you've got yourself a perfect performance that will be talked about for years to come. What this movie does to its viewers is fantastic, you're on the edge of your seat through all of its runtime which is about 2 hours. Joker is full of shocking scenes and so many surprises and it utilizes its R-rating very well. As we know this movie talks about mental illness and what it does to people and how it affects them specially when those people get abused or be made fun of, and Joker portrays this so perfectly that you even tend to sympathize with the main character, not that he is a good guy, he's not, he's the Joker after all, but by the way of how they portrayed this, you will be able to relate to this character and understand what he's going through so that by the time his story comes full circle and you see his character evolve to the clown prince of crime we all love to hate and hate to love, you'll be very satisfied and upset at the same time by how he becomes the Joker and it's all in a good way. Joker has quite the Easter eggs and references to other movies like the King of Comedy and Taxi Driver as the director Todd Phillips said that those two movies inspired him to do Joker, so you'll definitely feel some elements of those movies in here too. Talking about this movie without spoiling it is so difficult, but all i'll say is this: Joker is a drama masterpiece and it's not like any other comic book movie that's been made before, this is an original story that is based on the character "Joker" from DC comics but with a new and a deep origin story that is basically a character study that'll leave you wondering and thinking about how devastating it is by the time the credits start rolling.Verdict: Joker is one of those movies that after viewing, you will need to sit down and try to take it all in because it dives deep into what mental illness is and how it can affect people and how society can be a part of that transformation.

title: Surprisingly Excellent...HONESTLY
review:
Joker Review, No spoilers
My rating for Joker: 9.5 !
LOVED the movie!!! Had me thinking the whole time. Had its aha moments, moments of sadness and laughter. I am almost positive that we ALL laughed out loud at the same scenes...especially that one scene in the apartment near the end of the movie. Bringing up the 2 father figures and an ill mother really helped develop Arthur along with the tragedies that happened in his life.
His condition was believable based off of his excellent performance and animated laugh. Loved that Zazie Beetz was in this movie. Adored her character. Appreciated how a Joker movie was not all about Batman or Bruce Wayne. I couldn't have done the ending any better because the implication was perfect and they didn't have to spell it out for us. I'm convinced that Todd Phillips, the main producer, is an absolute genius. After watching this emotional rollercoaster, this movie deserves AT LEAST an Golden Globe nomination, if not a victory.
My only criticism is on some of the camera shots, although I understand how hard it is to make sure the main subject of the shots are always in the limelight. For instance, the train and bank scene . Also, depending on what kind of a movie watcher you are, you may not enjoy the layout of the music. For me, it was enjoyable.Do you think this joker movie will tie into Robert Pattinson's Batman movie?

title: A work of art
review:
I rarely give a perfect note but this movie deserves 100%. An origin story like you have never seen before. It seems so real that it could easily happen in the real world.
It points a finger to real life problems like desinstitutinalisation and the lack of help and follow up for people who suffer from psychiatric problems.
Joaquin Phoenix is absolutely incredible. He is not playing the Joker... he IS the Joker. His performance deserves an Academy Award. He is a method actor who transforms his body and his soul for his roles.
The cinematography (Lawrence Sher) is breathtaking. He is able to create a very heavy and dark ambiance that keeps us hooked. It's visually stunning. As the transformation of Arthur into the Joker advances, the camera makes the character seem bigger and just with that we can feel the confidence that he develops.
Todd Phillips has written, produced and directed was is, in my opinion, a work of art. The movie is heavy and difficult to watch at times. There are some very graphic and violent scenes but they are all necessary to the character development. I very rarely feel a deep internal unease as I watch a movie but I did as I watched how sad and tragic Arthur's life was.
The fact that they are able to make the watchers feel compassion for a psychopath is not an easy task.
The character development makes sense for once.
This is not a comic book movie. It's a character study.
Wow.

title: Send in the clowns.
review: One of the best aspects about DC's iconic Clown Prince of Crime, The Joker, is the ambiguity of his origins. Alan Moore's phenomenal graphic novel The Killing Joke (1988) provides us with one of the many possible origins for the character, but even Moore's renowned interpretation isn't considered to be the definitive backstory. Making his debut in Batman #1 in 1940, The Joker remains one of the most recognisable villains in the history of comics. Each appearance of The Joker, from The Dark Knight Returns (1986) to The Killing Joke, to Arkham Asylum: A Serious House on a Series Earth (1989) to Batman R.I.P (2008), and many, many more, stands as a uniquely different portrayal of the character, while still maintaining the core essence of his psychotic persona. Todd Philips' stand-alone origin story Joker is no exception. Arthur Fleck (Phoenix) is a party clown pursuing a career (unsuccessfully) as a stand up comedian in Gotham City. He lives in a rundown apartment with his mother, Penny (Frances Conroy), and suffers from a condition which causes him to laugh uncontrollably in inappropriate situations. Disregarded by society, Arthur slowly spirals into a life of crime, paving the way for the creation of his maniacal alter-ego, Joker.When it was announced Warner Bros. Pictures were developing a stand-alone Joker film, I was one of the many sceptics who claimed (with absolute confidence) that such an idea was unnecessary. Heath Ledger delivered an outstanding performance as The Joker in The Dark Knight (2008), and his portrayal has been long regarded as the highwater mark for those daring enough to adopt the role. Jared Leto's odd, over-the-top portrayal of the Clown Prince of Crime wasn't embraced by neither fans nor critics in 2016's terrible Suicide Squad, which led many to believe the Joker role had become untouchable since Ledger's critically acclaimed portrayal. However, in Joker, Joaquin Phoenix delivers an Oscar worthy performance as the titular character. Phoenix embodies the role perfectly; his performance doesn't mimic Ledgers (and rightfully steers clear of all Leto's shortcomings), and instead crafts a whole new take on the character while still maintaining the core essence of what makes The Joker so renowned. Phoenix brings a damaged realness to the role and embraces the sinister undercurrents of Fleck's mentally disturbed psyche. At times, he's downright unnerving. On occasion, I was reminded of Matt Dillon's performance as Jack in Lars von Trier's serial killer epic The House That Jack Built (2018). Both Arthur and Jack are mentally disturbed loners who harbour sinister urges, but what distinguishes Arthur Fleck from Trier's Jack (who, by all accounts, is a killer who isn't fumbling for validation in his crimes) is how he finds justification for enacting his own immoral sense of justice onto a society that has wrongfully disregarded him. It is important to note that you aren't coerced into rooting for Arthur as he descends further into madness. By no means is Joker portrayed as an antihero; you sympathise with him when the film begins, but this sympathy is short-lived once Fleck ultimately falls victim to his own heinous choices. From his maniacal laugh to his off-kilter, deranged mannerisms, Phoenix delivers a masterclass performance that would certainly make Ledger proud.Make no mistake, Joker is not what you've come to expect from the modern day comic book film. Philips and Silver have crafted a script that is grounded in reality and, at its core, it is a focused, psychological character study that trades in CGI spectacle (something that largely dominates comic book blockbusters these days) for mean-spirited, gritty nihilism. It's brilliantly constructed and certainly benefits from repeat viewings, as there is much of the film that is left open to interpretation. Hildur Gu√∞nad√≥ttir provides the film with a terrific score; it's brooding and eerily atmospheric, and stands as one of the best film scores of recent memory. It is a film dripping with atmosphere and tension that gradually elevates towards a finale that embraces the anarchy that Joker is known for. Joker has certainly garnered its fair share of controversy on the road towards its highly anticipated release, largely due to its violence and perceived influence it may inflict on audiences. While the film certainly has its violent moments, the violence never once overshadows the central narrative, nor is it as violent as the detractors would have you believe. What Joker ultimately serves as is a cautionary tale, while shining a light on how corruption can manifest within society.Joker is everything one could want from a Joker origin story. Dark, tense and fiercely gripping, it stands as one of the all time great Joker stories with a career best performance from Phoenix at the heart of it all. Destined to become a celebrated classic, Joker is this years must see film.

title: That's Life- Fits in like a glove
review: Joker is not a movie of pretense. It is about the truth.I think most people who disliked this movie disliked it because they were expecting some fairy tale, like they always do. But that's not the reality, is it? It hardly ever is. This movie portrays how much society can break you from within. This movie shows the struggle of a common man. It doesn't need any universe to follow, because it is a masterpiece on it's own.I went in to see a movie about this DC villain, but what did I get? I got exposed to the truth. It was certainly clever how the writers mixed a fictional character with someone who's living in this world and gave us something we kept thinking about hours after we came back from the theater.And Joaquin Phoenix's performance as Joker was as moving as the script. It was dark, it was bone-chilling and most importantly, it was brave. To portray a character like that, it takes guts. And he did justice.In all, it was worth it. Making this film was worth it. Received by many as a cold-hearted comedy, well you have it. That's life.

title: Best Joker's body language thus far.
review: Uniqueness of this production, when compared with Batman comic books, games and other movies, is undeniable. Joker's identity and his plans are very much the opposite of a mystery in here. This shift in perspective may just be what "Joker" needed to be the best movie based on a character from DC.For some reason, Joker is always taken very seriously by actors playing his role. Jack Nicolson's and Heath Ledger's Jokers were definitely phenomenal yet mostly acted by voice and facial expressions. It's fair to say that Joaquin Phoenix raised the bar by an order of magnitude. In his version of the Joker, voice acting and facial expressions are just minor parts of a bigger picture. His Joker moves like Joker. His Joker laughs and dances like Joker. It's very apparent how his Joker thinks, and he thinks like the Joker. He just feels like him. The level of immersion is unprecedented.Artistically, "Joker" is just beautiful. Music is perfect, Gotham feels enchanting but depressing, character costumes are very appealing. Whole experience is hypnotic, almost like in a comic book.Besides a true Joker and good Gotham, the movie contains some less important themes which aren't bad but may be distracting. It felt like they put two rather irrelevant scenes featuring young Bruce Wayne just for the sake of using the franchise. I also think that yet another version of Batman origins scene is the last thing a DC fan would like to see. All easily forgivable as everyone leaves their yaw on cinema floor anyway.

I definitely will have issues watching support hero's movies that will cover all the struggles and emotional drama in favor of punchlines and tension reliefs.2 out of 3 found this helpful.Was this review helpful?Sign into vote.Permalink

title: A Masterpiece which would have worked as great even if it had not relation with the BATMAN Universe
review: JOKER is a psychological study of the character, Not your regular comic book Movie. The movie forces audience to think deeply about issues regarding morality, mental health, bullying, the rich and the society as a whole. The main focus of the movie is the mind of Arthur and how it fragments apart under the many inhumane but impactful acts of the society which when pile up brings out the Joker in Arthur. What makes this hit the core of masses, is its relatability. He's a relatable kind of villain, bullied and sad. It also depicts how mental health issues are ignored by the corporates and the suffering people become even more isolated. Joaquin Phoenix has done a phenomenal job, even just looking at his laugh in which he has masterfully depicted the hidden sorrow behind the character, makes you realize that the man has worked hours and hours just to make this perfect. Cinematography was beautiful and the soundtrack suited the storyline perfectly. Even if the movie had no relation to the Batman universe at all, it would still have worked just as great. In the end, although you can't justify the acts of Arthur, but you definitely understand them.

title: Wow. Just wow.
review: I am beyond words. This movie is phenomenal. It is a masterpiece. Joaquin Phoenix definitely is my favorite live action Joker. Yes more than Heath and Jack (although i really HATE comparing them). This is not your typical comic book movie. It is a character study about a man who becomes the Joker. About what it took to drive him this far. The film is dark, disturbing and masterful work of art. Its one of the most beautiful movie i've ever seen. This movie deserves an Oscar. Not just beat actor, but best score, best cinema photography, best film and of course, best director, which definitely goes to the man Todd Philips. If Joaquin Phoenix doesn't get an oscar i'll riot. Believe the hype and screw the haters. Its truly beautiful. But dont just take my word for it, take all of the other 100's of positive reviews that say the same thing. I seriously wish there was a higher number than 10. This is like a 101/10. Just check it out. You won't regret it. title: Sometimes i remember it one way, sometimes i remember it another.
review:
The Joker has many origin stories, in comics, in movies or even series.
What this movie essentially does, is amplifies the best qualities that Joker offers.
It is a raw, sickening, intriguing and unsettling movie that understands what Joker is supposed to be, unpredictable, chaotic, the ebb which flows.I have so many good things to say, and literally no negativity towards this movie.
Amazing visuals, spectacular actor who portrays Joker, good music, stylish and memorable scenes.As a fan, this is everything i ever wanted. If this is your first Joker movie,
expect to be shocked, repulsed, disgusted, intrigued.
This is what Joker is, this is what joker has always been and should always be.A solid 10/10, i can't believe we live in a world where movies from DC can be this good.

title: Big Holes That Society Has, And Are Covered
review: I can resiliently say that Joker is a movie the world needed. Most critics get carried away by political, personal and sometimes illicit influences as they review it. In this way it presents a disturbed view of masterful works. Joker touches delicate subjects in a way that is rarely seen in today's theaters. If the world can't handle a profound work like, then it means the world needs to change. And change the way we view complex social issues, which we prefer to isolate it from debate because of the high diversity of opinion. Very well built and set, Joker brings big holes that society has, and are covered.2 out of 3 found this helpful.Was this review helpful?Sign into vote.Permalink

title: Speechless.. Stunned !!
review: My review is incomplete as there is so much to discuss but i am speechless.. This is by far one of the most "well done" movie based on the life of a mentally ill person. You are very much instilled in the shoe of a person who has mental illness and has to face the modern day society who expect him to behave.. as if he doesn't !! For me this move is 1 step beyond another master piece called "Memento (2000)" which was also based on a mentally ill character. But Joker is an extensively Dark movie for a main-stream Cinema specially when he is dancing he is sending a layered message to the audience. Most of the times this movie gives you the feel of an Art Movie (more than just an action flick or superhero flick). The dark and disturbing part of this movie is sheer work of Art that too performed with utter brilliance. And last but not least, Phoenix is by far the best and most Realistic Joker ever.. for me he did a PERFECT job of not only Joker but also a mentally ill person.. Perfect expression, laughter and dialogue delivery .. In the End Please NOTE: that when i said 'mentally ill' i meant a person Not Fit for modern day hypocrite Society : )

title: All I have are positive thougts

I fully recommend this movie to all the fans of the dark knight and to those who love character development and interesting dialogues and quotes and generally movies that keep you thinking hard for weeks. So it is important to remember that this Joker is a different version of the character and so you should not hope for another 2008-Joker. Moreover, it is not a Nolan movie and so its main theme and focus are different from the Dark Knight since Joker is a drama-thriller movie. title: It's so much more than a character study.
review: There is a danger to this film.An origin story, sure. But a warning about how society, friends and family can slowly wear away at a person - and how there's no time taken by anyone to understand anyone who is struggling, is different, who's 'failing'.Like driving and parenting, those who are poor at these things, seldom realise just how bad they are. With social responsibility and awareness, people are just the same. Everyone thinks they're good. Posted that suicide awareness meme? Tick. I'm a solid human being. Then post a video of that weirdo on the bus.The film has divided many. I suspect that those who've not enjoyed it are those with little empathy or those lucky enough not to have an ignored struggle to cope with. Certainly not adrift from society, or failing to 'achieve' (urgh). It's quite likely the film's closing line was a predictor of those reactions. I was the only one laughing at this and a few other moments.Phoenix cuts through his character's psyche here more than Joker does any victim. He breathes and cries loneliness. There are several moments which openly show his struggle to join in with a world he doesn't fit into. He waltzes through these and more, pulling you on-side and deeper and deeper. And I felt it. Very much.And that's where it could be dangerous. A potential call to arms.But above all, it's a remarkably engrossing piece, linking as much with King Of Comedy as with the Batman story. Drawing the links between the two worlds into focus too, and forcing us to question our ignorance and to challenge known truths.Phoenix will win Best Actor for this. Rightly so.

title: Is the Joker the misfit or the society?
review:
This film shows the human side of the Joker, the mental illness, not being acepted by the society and being humiliated. He is raised with traditional values and has deep connections with his mother who inspired him to make people laugh as his life mission.
Is the Joker the misfit or the society we are living in has lost its ways, looking down to care of older people and focusing on seeing only the deviations from the standard way of behaving, standard way of talking and standard way of dressing and looking like.
In the beginning the Joker thought his life is a tragedy, in the end he understood it is a comedy.2 out of 3 found this helpful.Was this review helpful?Sign into vote.Permalink

title: Incredible dark gritty movie, forget rich powerful superheros, this is the time of the underdog.
review: After falling out of love with the Marvel & DC universes and now pretty much giving up on all super hero movies altogether, I was apathetic when the ads for Joker first appeared in my local cinema. I looked at my 16 year old son, who loves watching movies too, and we both shared the same thought: "yeah whatever"....But as the trailer rolled, it started to look interesting. Then I checked facebook, and friends who had seen the trailer too were talking excitedly. Someone said "in Marvel they take a human and give him superpowers, here we have the opposite, a man who has everything taken away from him" and that really resonated with me.This is one of the most important movies of our time, starring one of the most important actors of our time, the incredible Joaquin Phoenix, who has blazed a trail of cinematic excellence for many years and who's career, I think, culminates to huge climax here in this film.It's dark, dark, dark. So damn gritty and real the camera work gives us this filthy downtrodden vision of Gotham and city on the brink of self destruction. No one flys or has a special suit there are no superpowers, or laser beams, there is just a man being spat out by the system, which is run by the rich for the rich and is becoming increasingly greedy and selfish. Included in this system is the Wayne family, who despite whatever their intentions actually are, are presented here as little more than white over privileged rich people who live in a huge gated house with private security. Yeah whatever Bruce but did you ever really spend time in the ghetto?This is the commentary and Joker is trying, he's really trying to absorb the hate and the crap and the downright hardship that life is throwing at him, but he lacks the presence of mind to do it quite literally, struggles with an insane urge to laugh all the time even when things are absolutely not funny and of course the rest is history.I hope this doesn't spoil it for you, go and watch it, that's 2 hours of your life you will want to repeat.

title: Perhaps the most human villain I've ever seen
review: If watching this film was a game of chess, you'd be playing against an opponent who won the game before it even started. No matter how you defend your king, your opponent outmaneuvers you and penetrates your emotional defenses every step of the way. Other directors should take notes because this is character study drama at its finest.While some will say it moved too slowly, I personally feel it was paced perfectly given the content; a slow-bleeding, 'death by a thousand cuts' delivery, which gradually ramps up over the course of the entire film. The juxtaposition of humor and despair had my emotions on a tilt-a-whirl throughout, and was accompanied by a soundtrack that complemented the themes very well.I highly recommend watching this one at least once, but steel yourself because it packs quite a punch.2 out of 3 found this helpful.Was this review helpful?Sign into vote.Permalink

title: An experience one must have!!
review:
Let me just say that no, the praise everyone has heard about this before it released was not the usual overhyping of a movie from critics at festivals, it was 100% deserved, I completely understand why it got an 8 minute standing ovation at Venice and yes, I did clap when this movie ended, and so did the packed audience at the theatre I went to.I mean, can you blame me? From the minute "Joker" starts you are glued to the screen, I literally did not avert my gaze for a second. Joaquin Phoenix gives probably the best performance of his life (and that's saying something) and definitely deserves an Oscar nomination.The story, even though a tad predictable, is amazingly written, full of great moments, both funny and dramatic and really shows
us why Arthur Fleck decides to turn into the homicidal maniac that is the Joker.Overall this is probably my favourite comic-book movie of all time, if not just my favourite movie of all time, the way Todd Philips directed his feature is astonishing, I mean this movie looks sooooo good and I, for one, cannot wait to see what he does in the future.A+

title: Witness the magic of cinematography as it was always meant to be!
review: Yep! I will need to see this at least once again to fully understand how great it was. I don't think I have seen such deep dive into insanity since a good while. As the story slowly unfolds a very unsettling sensation took hold of me because I ashamedly realised I sympathise with Arthur Fleck and his actions. The cinematography is purely superb and finally I have seen a new colour palette that wasn't repeated a thousand times. There were so many potentially iconic scenes that will become memes and film history, that on its own makes this movie worthy of appraisal. I'd love to see how Joaquin Phoenix went inside the head of the Joker, because he definitely studied symptoms of insanity in depth. So many great things been already said about this film, I won't repeat those. The last 20 minutes of the film is freaking intense and when the Joker finally let all his will to pretend to be sane go, you will witness an unparalleled transformation that's not going to be forgotten or topped by anyone in our lifetime. There were so many moments in Fleck's life when he could have been helped or stopped, but society just didn't care for him. Hunted, bullied, despised, ridiculed and ultimately lied to by everyone including his closest relatives...no wonder he became the Joker. I am so happy this movie could happen in this time and age of ultra sensitivity and its reception is so overwhelming. In the diarrhoea of degenerate Disney flicks here we have a movie that will make people think and talk about it for hours on end. And finally f..k the Oscar for Best Movie, this movie already won the most significant award in Venice where real cinematic art is awarded not the best money making scheme. Joaquin Phoenix deserves the Oscar for Best Actor of 2019. Nothing I have seen this year touches his performance...not a thing! Oh, the soundtrack. How could I not mention the heart wrenching score by the Icelandic cello artist and composer Hildur Gudnadottir?! Anyone remembers the subway scene and then the following impromptu dance in the toilet with that amazing score in the background? That's called perfection!üëçüèª

title: I've seen sociopathy up close, this is the real deal!
review:
This movie made me create an account to review it.
I've watched it twice in the cinema in 12 hours.
Here's the thing, I studied sociopathy for a few months after seeing it up close in a close person. Joaquin Phoenix didn't just deliver what may be the best performance an actor ever gifted the world (perhaps tied with Branston Cranston's Walter White in Breaking Bad).
But he behaves exactly like a sociopath does, with an origin story that perfectly maps that of many sociopaths - which I won't spoil you with.
He should get one Oscar for best actor, and one for accuracy and realism.
This is not just a movie, it a scientific achievement and it will be used by psychologists and psychiatrists for Aeons to come.
This movie is currently rated 9.2 despite Marvel fans voting it 1 star just to make Endgame higher.
Do the math and you'll see, that means that Joker is right now the highest rated movie in history. Anyone who criticizes Joaquin's perfomance is simply a fortunate person, who never actually met a sociopath and can't understand what they're seeing.
This movie will still be remembered a century from now.2 out of 3 found this helpful.Was this review helpful?Sign into vote.Permalink

title: In your face call for justice that upsets the corrupt elite
review: There is a reason why this masterpiece is being panned by the crony capitalist critics. It challenges their all too comfortable fake construction of reality and it does so in such an effective way, that it almost automatically elicits a dishonest, knee-jerk defensive reaction from them, frightened to the bone that their gaslighting charade might get uncovered. It is not Joker that is delusional, it is they that sell delusions in order to maintain the status quo.But, eventually, and they know it, you get what you deserve. That sentence and that sentiment is what so scares them, because this movie cuts too close to the bone, and like all great, game-changing art, it is just a bit too true.When Joker, who is a true hero here, helps a character, equally mistreated by the powers that be, go free, he points that he was the only one that treated him well. This is a call for kindness that is essence of the movie, but it is barely noticed by those who, like the villain of the movie, Thomas Wayne, think we are all despicable clowns. So they lie and pool wool over our eyes, as they only can, misconstrue and make false scares, so that the point of the movie that is most damaging for them would not get across.All these are marks of a great movie. In Europe, it was instantly recognized - and rewarded, for the subversive potential it has. In North America, it scared the hell out of conformists, and the reaction was, for many, an almost reflexive rejection. Which means it hit, it hit hard, quite uncomfortably so. And if anything the hypo crites hate so much, it is the movie that exposes them, and, even more so, exposes the paper tiger of the blood sucking system they depend on for what it is.

review: Too many movies out there of unhinged characters that are way more problematic to blame this one for the state of violence in America. title: Phoenix and Phillips craft a masterpiece
review: This is the greatest depiction of a comic book charachter in a movie of all time. Phoenix inhabits this man outcast by society and destined to be the greatest villain Gotham has ever known, and puts his all into it. His performance of a man who's been persecuted his whole life for his mental conditions was immaculate. He brings this charachter to life like no one ever has (Ledger included). Another aspect that can't be swept under the rug is how Impressive of a directing job Phillips did. The fact that he is able to move from directing some of the most renound comedies of all time, to crafting this intense character piece is a credit to his unbelievable skill. The Joker has always been depicted as existing in a world outside of ours, but in this dark drama it's accuratley shown what it would be like if this villain actually existed in the real world. An aspect of this film that's likely not going to get as much attention as it should from general audiences is the score. It's brilliant, and elevates this movie to a whole other level. Don't even hesitate if thinking about watching this movie, do yourself a favor and immerse yourself in this expertly conceived world.

title: A character study of a broken man who finally decides to embrace his insanity, that just so happens to be based on a popular comic book character.
review:
'Joker' is not a comic book movie about the origin of a supervillain. Instead, it is a character study of a broken man who finally decides to embrace his insanity, that just so happens to be produced by a recognisable brand. And oh man, how I wish more mainstream films were like this.Joaquin Phoenix delivers a career-defining powerhouse performance as the lead that also arguably redefines the Joker. Whereas the character has previously been portrayed as a criminal mastermind that poses an unstoppable foil to Batman, or in Jared Leto's case, just a joke, Phoenix achieves something I previously thought unfathomable; he makes the character sympathetic.
This Joker, or more precisely, Arthur Fleck, is just an ordinary individual you could easily encounter in the street, who's constantly laughing from the pain of his mere existence. This guy can't catch a break, as he is continuously pushed around and mentally tormented by the world around him, and I could not help but feel pity and remorse for the guy. Even the most subtle nuances Phoenix imposes, such as his changing tone of voice or the way he walks makes his portrayal feel all the more real. When Fleck finally snaps back at the world, I didn't necessarily barrack for him, as his actions are violent and gruesome. However, I was deeply fascinated by how Fleck finally accepts himself as a sociopathic maniac and seeks his own personal justice through the persona of the Joker.
The rest of the supporting cast does a serviceable job, especially Robert De Niro, who hasn't given a performance this lively in years. But Phoenix is the main attraction, and rightfully so. To make the comparison to Heath Ledger's Joker and argue who's better would be pointless. This is a very different portrayal, and I believe the best of both worlds should be embraced.Apart from my ravings about Phoenix, I was very impressed with Todd Phillips' direction, especially considering his previous filmography comprises of sex comedies. Without going too far into spoiler territory, I found the way Phillips chose to tell this story pleasantly surprising. It takes a similar route to something like 'Fight Club' or 'American Psycho', wherein you're unsure whether all the events unfolding on-screen are actually happening in reality or merely the character's imagination. I believe it could be an entirely plausible origin for the Joker in the comics.
Under Phillips' guidance, the majority of the stylistic features are efficiently executed. The muted colour palette and handheld cinematography compliment the film's gritty, realistic tone very well. Hildur Gu√∞nad√≥ttir's score, which is mainly comprised of cellos and other stringed instruments, is hauntingly beautiful. It subtly underscores the Joker's deeper delving into crime and insanity until it crescendos into an anxiety-inducing orchestra when full-on chaos unfolds.My only issue with the film is despite its aims to be a standalone character study, it still dares to shoehorn in tributes and references to the comics. This is only done to a minor extent but it just felt jarring because it did not contribute to the story being told whatsoever.Although I had optimistic hopes for this film, I was still blown away by it. Overall, it was just nice to see a comic book movie that isn't part of a greater cinematic universe that has to set up multiple sequels. Despite all the controversy and criticism swirling around the film's release, I have no doubt over time it will be considered one of the great films of this decade. It is not the perfect comic book movie, but it is rather, the most personal comic book movie I've ever seen.

title: Confronting and masterful
review: I did not know what to expect from this film but what I walked away with was an appreciation of the master of his craft that is Joaquin Phoenix. His gradual metamorphosis into a man disconnected and disassociated with society and its norms is quite simply brilliant. No other actor could have performed this role so well. He is mesmerising. The story is riveting and confronting. The city of Gotham, covered in rubbish and rats is a powerful metaphor for the decay of society and its civility. It is represented as cruel, cold, and degenerating into chaos. There is no reprieve, no hero to save the day. We are exposed to our real selves otherwise hidden by the mask worn by Arthur Fleck. The script, cinematography and score are sublime but Phoenix is the star of this film and must win an Oscar for this role. There is no performance in recent times that compares to it.2 out of 3 found this helpful.Was this review helpful?Sign into vote.Permalink

title: It should have been Commodus (Gladiator) 19 years ago - It'll be Arthur Fleck
review: 19 years ago, Joaqin Phoenix was robbed of his Oscar but this time it'll be almost impossible to top this performance this year in movies.Phoenix dazzles as this sort of distressed, twisted character that has everything in life going against him. Gotham truly is a cruel city and you end the movie questioning whose side you're on.The links to to Wayne family in this picture also grow the folklore around the Joker-Batman dynamic and you get a greater sense as to why their stories are so intertwined. Really classy touch.Going into this, I felt this 2hour + movie would drag but each and every scene meshes well together, the 1st act makes you grow attached to Arthur as he battles against these demons in his life and the middle & final acts pay your patience with a bunch of twists & turns that you didn't see coming.Worth every second, tightly written script and I can't wait for what DC has in store for us moving forward with these stand alone features. 10/10

title: AN ABSOLUTE MASTERPIECE
review:
I have been a film aficionado since as long as I can remember and there is a very select few films I consider to be a masterpiece. On that list is Kubrick's Full Metal Jacket, Tarantino's Pulp Fiction and De Palma's Carrie. I have now added Todd Phillip's Joker.
Joaquin Pheonix is incredible and deserves every bit of the Oscar. You forget Pheonix is even in this film because you are so lost in his character. The score is magnificent, that was actually my first thought after watching this film, I thought it would be a crime if Joker didn't win the Oscar for best score.
The way the story ties into the world of Gotham and Batman is extra bonus. You must not forget the setting this movie takes place. Your brain wants to say it's New York City, but it's not. It's Gotham.1 out of 1 found this helpful.Was this review helpful?Sign into vote.Permalink

title: the revolution
review: As usual in a case where people leap to extremes, the truth is somewhere in the middle. Joker may make some people who feel marginalized feel more seen and more powerful, and they may act out in response. There are some ugly, self-serving messages in the movie, which is incongruously bent on creating sympathy for Batman's worst enemy and one of DC Comics' most notoriously callous mass murderers and atrocity architects. But love it or hate it, the film does spin up a tempting fantasy of persecution and relief, of embracing nihilism as a means of complete escape from a terrible world1 out of 1 found this helpful.Was this review helpful?Sign into vote.Permalink

title: A haunting drama about one of the greatest villains ever.
review: I now think I could've actually seen it while it was playing in cinemas. It was really a somber, dark and disturbing drama film that only got better with every passing second. Joaquin Phoenix has delivered a really outstanding performance, and now I really believe it, having seen it myself! Also, kudos to Todd Phillips for not only directing it brilliantly but also for keeping it less than 2 hours and focusing on just the important parts.Joker is not a superhero film despite being set in the same universe as Batman. It's a very, very dark film that is just hard to "enjoy". It's entertaining and captivating, but not in the way you might think. There are no "wow" moments in it, and all I could feel was sad at times for Arthur before he became the Joker.Joker is definitely not for you if you're easily turned off by some graphic gore or afraid of disturbing characters. If Todd intended to show us the human beneath the psychopath, I'd say he won, at least for more than half of the movie's duration. Joker has got a strong performance from Phoenix, intense conversations and also some really gorgeous visuals. This film is like a comic book that turns out to be a pretty good character study.

title: A true masterpiece!
review:
I have notice a lot of people try to draw comprising which (in my view) are completely missed.
This is not a typical DC/superhero type movie. It has nothing to do with Heath Ledger. Would he be proud? Probably. He was brilliant in his own way; however he stared in a DC movie and was your typical Joker (having said that he executed it brilliantly).Now, this movie is different - it is a case study of mental illness. Very deep and heavy going, nonetheless accurate and beautiful in a way. It may as well be considered a movie on its own, without any connections with Gotham, the Joker character, the comic books etc etc. If anything - Taxi Driver (1976) and the King of Comedy (1982) are closer to it than any of the Batman or other DC shows you have seen in the past.Joaquin Phoenix is the best actor of his generation. By far and undoubtedly.
What he did in this film is remarkable. I left the cinema absolutely speechless and moved at the same time.
It is a masterpiece!

title: Brilliant and Grim Masterpiece
review: In recent years, superhero movies have filled the theaters. This film is unlike any of them. Gritty and realistic it's label as dangerous by the media is well-deserved. This is not because of excessive violence but rather, it is because Arthur Fleck is such a relatable and sympathetic character for so many people.He's not a full-blown psychotic nor is he a calculated psychopath. He is a generally polite, lonely and isolated guy who is in that in between. He's healthy enough to work a job but not healthy enough to thrive or excel. His head is just barely above water, so to speak. His unraveling throughout the movie has less to do with a worsening illness like schizophrenia and more to do with the realistic actions of the society around him.By brilliantly using an accurate depiction of society's actions as a mechanism for his development, it creates a story that rings true. It also creates a deeply sympathetic and almost justified character. Unlike Heath Ledger's agent of chaos Joker, this Joker is fighting against a society that has genuinely failed and mistreated him (and so many others, as the ending shows).All in all, I would say this movie was a masterpiece. It explained a realistic and interesting backstory for a character who is really part of the fabric of American culture. It also highlighted a very overlooked segment of society and looked at real issues that they are facing.
